result.execSummary:
The defendant Chadwick C Smith was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse, Use of a Dangerous Weapon], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Bond of $150 applied to court costs/balance due during term of probation. If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, in addition to all other enforcement sanctions available to the court, a civil judgment enforceable by all creditors' remedies shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.

-AODA and any counseling/treatment deemed appropriate.
-Absolute sobriety.
-No controlled substances or prescription medication unless prescribed by physician and in conformity with said prescription.
-Randoms tests.
-No violent contact with the victim or his minor son.
-Submit DNA sample.
-Pay supervision fees.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

Defendant Chadwick C Smith in court with attorney Michael Girard Penkwitz.  Jeffrey A Sisley appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Plea of no contest to the complaint entered by defendant. Court is informed the State needs to comply with the victims rights. Court accepts plea and finds defendant guilty. Court recess for victim to contact District Attorney. Case recalled at 9:25 am. All parties present. Court is informed victim contacted their office and does wish to be present.  Court renders sentence.
Further proceedings at 08-12-2015 08:45 am
